Award.AwardTitle: High-Strength Carbon Fibers from Eco-Friendly Processing of Biomass

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Carbon fibers are among the strongest known reinforcing fibers used in a wide range of commercial composite materials. Because the element carbon does not melt, carbon fibers need to be obtained from organic precursors. Among renewable feedstocks, lignin is starting to play an important role as a potential precursor for carbon fibers, owing to its significant carbon content. However, the irregular chemical architecture of lignin makes the resulting carbon network very inefficient. Therefore, the resulting carbon-fiber properties are still significantly lower than those obtained from currently used synthetic polyacrylonitrile precursor, which involves the use of strong solvents and leads to toxic off-gases such as hydrogen cyanide. This research project is directed towards the development of a green precursor and an efficient processing route to obtain high strength carbon fibers.

Lignin is readily available as an inexpensive by-product from Kraft paper mills, but this untreated form contains too many impurities to be used in high-performance products such as carbon fibers. Recently, Clemson researchers have discovered a renewable solvent that can purify Kraft lignin and isolate a high molecular weight lignin fraction in the solvated state. Clemson researchers (in a separate project) have also shown that dry-spinning of non-fractionated, acetylated lignin can lead to carbon fibers with enhanced strength. Therefore, the research team hypothesizes that the solvated lignin precursor will enable direct dry-spinning of precursor fibers, followed by their conversion to microstructure-controlled, high-performance carbon fibers. The specific research objectives are (i) control of the molecular architecture of fractionated-solvated lignin precursors (ii) rheological evaluation of suitable solvated lignin fractions to measure strain-hardening for efficient dry-spinning of precursor fibers, and (iii) microstructural control to obtain superior performance in the resulting carbon fibers. The intellectual significance of this research is that lignin fractions with controlled molecular weight and architecture will provide a unique materials platform for studying the rheological and microstructural (rheo-structural) behavior of these bio-derived fluids. Specifically, a long-linear architecture will be identified that leads to strain-hardening during extensional flow, a desirable phenomenon for stable dry-spinning of fibers. It is hypothesized that the control of molecular architecture of the fractionated-solvated lignin will lead to the efficient formation of graphitic carbon and superior properties for the resulting carbon fibers.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Carbon fibers are among the strongest known reinforcing fibers used in a wide range of commercial composite materials.  Because bulk carbon does not melt, the fine diameter carbon fibers need to be obtained from organic precursors. Among renewable feedstocks, lignin is starting to play an important role as a potential precursor for carbon fibers.  However, the irregular chemical architecture of lignin makes the resulting carbon network very inefficient. Therefore, the resulting carbon fiber properties are still significantly lower than those obtained from currently used synthetic polyacrylonitrile precursor that gives off toxic gases such as hydrogen cyanide. Therefore, this project focused on the use of lignin as the precursor because it is an environmentally friendly precursor. This route has significant positive societal impact because lignin is the second most abundant non-food biomass readily available as an inexpensive by-product from Kraft paper mills.

 In two separate prior studies, Clemson researchers had established that (A) a renewable solvent that can purify/isolate a high molecular weight lignin fraction in the solvated state, and (B) dry-spinning of non-fractionated, acetylated lignin can lead to carbon fibers with enhanced strength.  Therefore, the extended Clemson group collaborated to hypothesize that the solvated lignin precursor could enable direct dry-spinning of precursor fibers, followed by their conversion to microstructure-controlled, high-performance carbon fibers. The specific research objectives were to: (i) obtain desired lignin precursors by an efficient, single-step fractionation-solvation process, (ii) relate the lignin structure to flow behavior of the solvated lignin fractions for efficient dry-spinning of precursor fibers, and (iii) control microstructure of the precursor and carbonization process to obtain superior performance in the resulting carbon fibers.

The intellectual merit of the completed research is that lignin fractions with controlled molecular weight provided a unique materials platform for studying the flow behavior of precursor solution that led to enhanced microstructure and superior, high strength carbon fibers. Specifically, the simultaneous purification and fractionation of lignin was accomplished using the ALPHA process to obtain lignin precursors with molecular weights of about 7000, 14000, and 28000 Da. The highest molecular weight fraction obtained in this study (28,000) was shown to result in excellent dry-spinning of the solvated lignin fraction, proving that larger chains lead to strain-hardening during extensional flow encountered during fiber draw-down. The lignin fibers were oxidatively stabilized and successfully converted to carbon fibers. Although the extent of graphitic crystallinity was low, the presence of ordered graphitic domains was demonstrated by x-ray diffraction and transmission electron microscopy. The highest molecular weight lignin fraction led to the most ordered carbonaceous microstructure. In turn, the resulting carbon fibers were shown to possess a tensile strength and modulus of 1.4 GPa and 98 GPa, among the highest values reported to date for lignin-based carbon fibers.

 

 


Last Modified: 09/13/2019
Modified by: Amod A Ogale
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Carbon fibers are among the strongest known reinforcing fibers used in a wide range of commercial composite materials. Because bulk carbon does not melt, the fine diameter carbon fibers need to be obtained from organic precursors. Among renewable feedstocks, lignin is starting to play an important role as a potential precursor for carbon fibers. However, the irregular chemical architecture of lignin makes the resulting carbon network very inefficient. Therefore, the resulting carbon fiber properties are still significantly lower than those obtained from currently used synthetic polyacrylonitrile precursor that gives off toxic gases such as hydrogen cyanide. Therefore, this project focused on the use of lignin as the precursor because it is an environmentally friendly precursor. This route has significant positive societal impact because lignin is the second most abundant non-food biomass readily available as an inexpensive by-product from Kraft paper mills. In two separate prior studies, Clemson researchers had established that (A) a renewable solvent that can purify/isolate a high molecular weight lignin fraction in the solvated state, and (B) dry-spinning of non-fractionated, acetylated lignin can lead to carbon fibers with enhanced strength. Therefore, the extended Clemson group collaborated to hypothesize that the solvated lignin precursor could enable direct dry-spinning of precursor fibers, followed by their conversion to microstructure-controlled, high-performance carbon fibers. The specific research objectives were to: (i) obtain desired lignin precursors by an efficient, single-step fractionation-solvation process, (ii) relate the lignin structure to flow behavior of the solvated lignin fractions for efficient dry-spinning of precursor fibers, and (iii) control microstructure of the precursor and carbonization process to obtain superior performance in the resulting carbon fibers. The intellectual merit of the completed research is that lignin fractions with controlled molecular weight provided a unique materials platform for studying the flow behavior of precursor solution that led to enhanced microstructure and superior, high strength carbon fibers. Specifically, the simultaneous purification and fractionation of lignin was accomplished using the ALPHA process to obtain lignin precursors with molecular weights of about 7000, 14000, and 28000 Da. The highest molecular weight fraction obtained in this study (28,000) was shown to result in excellent dry-spinning of the solvated lignin fraction, proving that larger chains lead to strain-hardening during extensional flow encountered during fiber draw-down. The lignin fibers were oxidatively stabilized and successfully converted to carbon fibers. Although the extent of graphitic crystallinity was low, the presence of ordered graphitic domains was demonstrated by x-ray diffraction and transmission electron microscopy. The highest molecular weight lignin fraction led to the most ordered carbonaceous microstructure. In turn, the resulting carbon fibers were shown to possess a tensile strength and modulus of 1.4 GPa and 98 GPa, among the highest values reported to date for lignin-based carbon fibers.
